channel.title: Can someone
channel.description: Give me their Enviromental paths, nothings running and i've installed JDK and verified it's there. Thanks..

item.title: Can someone
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“pr0stbeef, post:14, topic:217011”]C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator> Javac -Version
javac version 1.6.0_10-beta[/quote]

You should now be able to compile fine. I’m assuming your using some overly complicated scripts for running/compiling servers that aren’t needed.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“pr0stbeef, post:12, topic:217011”]C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator> Java -Version java version "1.6.0_10-beta" ava <TM> Client VM <buid 11.0-b12, mixed mode, sharing>

That’s what came up.
Still can’t compile/run a server
Still can’t run a client.[/quote]

Do a “javac -version” then post it here.

Read full topic

item.title: Can someone
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“pr0stbeef, post:10, topic:217011”]Okay, I found it.
C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jdk1.6.0_10\bin[/quote]

Now make a new (user) variable with the name path and the value “C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jdk1.6.0_10\bin”(no quotes). Close all command prompt windows, open one and type “java --version”, if it still says Java cannot be recognised then post back here.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: Can someone
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“pr0stbeef, post:8, topic:217011”][quote author=Niall link=topic=285266.msg2311256#msg2311256 date=1215060331]

and thanks Niall for the help, but it didn’t work.

You asked for my variables and you got it, you didn’t ask for help.

My computer is 64bit too, and I have the 32bit version of Java.

Add the variable path with the value:
C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin

If that doesn’t work, go to C:\Program Files\Java\ and write down the name of the JDK folder with the highest number after it, then change the path variable to this:
C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\bin

That will add both the JRE that came with JDK, and JDK to it.
[/quote]

I wasn’t being sarcastic, I appreciate the help even if I can’t get it to work. It’s just a little frustrating, nothing is done to System Variables? Just user variables?

And, I went to My computer > Local Disk (C:) > Program Files > ? After that there’s no Java file.[/quote]

Yes, only do the user variables.

Go to C:\Program Files, find your Java folder, go in it, then go in your bin folder, copy the full path and post it here.

You also need to close all command prompts before changes take effect.

Read full topic

[quote author=pr0stbeef link=topic=285266.msg2311241#msg2311241 date=1215059802]and thanks Niall for the help, but it didn’t work.

You asked for my variables and you got it, you didn’t ask for help.

Add the variable path with the value:
C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin

If that doesn’t work, go to C:\Program Files\Java\ and write down the name of the JDK folder with the highest number after it, then change the path variable to this:
C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\bin

That will add both the JRE that came with JDK, and JDK to it.[/quote]

I wasn’t being sarcastic, I appreciate the help even if I can’t get it to work. It’s just a little frustrating, nothing is done to System Variables? Just user variables?

And, I went to My computer > Local Disk (C:) > Program Files > ? After that there’s no Java file.

item.title: Can someone
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

pr0stbeef:

and thanks Niall for the help, but it didn’t work.

You asked for my variables and you got it, you didn’t ask for help.

My computer is 64bit too, and I have the 32bit version of Java.

Add the variable path with the value:
C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin

If that doesn’t work, go to C:\Program Files\Java\ and write down the name of the JDK folder with the highest number after it, then change the path variable to this:
C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\jre\bin;C:\Program Files\Java\YOUR JDK FOLDER HERE\bin

That will add both the JRE that came with JDK, and JDK to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Can someone
item.dc:creator: @Rayne Rayne
item.description:
@Rayne wrote:

Excerpt from my tut. Not leeched.

First go to control panel>system>advanced options>enviormental variables. Here it will show user variables and system variables. Do not mess with the system variables. First in the user variables create a new user variable and name it CLASSPATH. For the variable value add this -
Code: (java)

CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin;%CLASSPATH%

Next create another user variable and name it PATH. For the variable value add this -
Code: (java)

C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06\bin

Read full topic
